awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: 3-D Stellar Hydrodynamics of Convective Boundary Mixing and Shell Mergers in Massive Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
The evolution of stars and their ultimate fate as white dwarfs, white dwarf supernovae, neutron stars, or black holes remains at the center of research in astronomy.  This question relates to diverse research topics in time domain astronomy, supernova research, nuclear astrophysics, galactic chemical evolution, asteroseismology, stellar populations, and the formation and evolution of stars and structure in the early universe.  However, the fundamental macroscopic stellar physics process of convection remains poorly understood.  Although there is some good theory, surprisingly accurate despite being rather simplistic, realistic studies must rely on computationally intensive simulations.  That is what this project will enable, and perform.  It will have a large impact on stellar evolution theory, providing cutting edge techniques and innovative methods of wide applicability.  The study supports one graduate and up to three undergraduate students, and the results will be used in course teaching.

The details, especially the study of mergers of convective shells, such as the C- and O-burning shells of massive stars, as well as convective boundary mixing, can only be realistically captured in complex three-dimensional (3D) hydrodynamics simulations.  This project will build on prior work to pursue three main objectives: (1) validation of a 1D model of convective boundary mixing, using brief 3D stellar hydrodynamics simulations relevant to massive stars near the ends of their lives; (2) assessment of when two convective shells right on top of each other can in fact merge, using the model from (1) combined with 3D simulation; and (3) for shell merger cases, use 3D hydrodynamical simulations to study when nearby shells exchange their chemical abundance mixtures.  Prior studies in 1D indicate that the convection zone above the O-burning shell could incorporate enough material from above it to reach the C-burning shell.  This could cause odd-Z elements like potassium, scandium, and chlorine to be produced in greater abundance.  A sequence of brief 3D simulations alternating with longer 1D simulations will show in detail the approach to, and ultimate result of, the shell merger process.  The large database of results on convective boundary mixing will be organized and made available, together with the tools that mine it, analyze it, and display its results, to enable unanticipated research by the greater community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved an active collaboration of our team at the University of Minnesota, led by P.I. Paul Woodward, with Falk Herwig's team at the University of Victoria in Canada.  This project focused on detailed 3-D simulations of convective boundary mixing in massive stars.  A large number of such simulations were carried out on the NSF’s Frontera computing system at TACC using our PPMstar simulation code.  Many interesting results were found, but the most important are likely to be the results of a long and detailed investigation of convective boundary mixing in core convection, leading to the formation of a region of penetrative convection beyond the Schwarzschild boundary (SB).

By carefully examining a series of long-duration simulations of core convection in the correct spherical geometry and with a fully realistic stellar model, we were able to produce a new 1-D model of convection that includes a penetration region beyond the SB.  Finding a way to predict the extent of a penetrative region of convection and to understand what limits this extent has been a major outstanding problem in stellar astrophysics for many years.  In our original project plan, we had not expected that we would be able to come up with such a model.  Instead, we had assumed that we would adopt a model already in use that bundled the information about the 3-D processes that is missing in a 1-D calculation into one or two unknown dimensionless parameters that we could calculate by carrying out fully 3-D simulations for a large set of representative cases.  By the end of this project, and after the funding of its continuation by award 2309101, we have converged on a model that requires that we know the kinetic energy dissipation rate in the convective region up to the SB.

We cannot know the kinetic energy dissipation rate in a 1-D stellar evolution computation, but we can estimate it, or we can compute it using a 3-D simulation that runs only for a relatively short duration on a modest grid.  We can perform a number of 3-D simulations to produce the kinetic energy dissipation rate up to the SB that our new 1-D model requires to permit interpolation for any cases of interest.  We can select a functional form for the shape of the transition at the convective boundary of the radiative diffusion flux, such as the sine wave between its extrema or tanh(arcsinh(x)) to get a sharper transition, and then adopt a validated scaling law such as the thickness of this transition region varying with the 1/3 power of the luminosity.  Aside from these choices, which can of course be validated, we believe that there are no ad hoc parameters that enter into our new 1-D model of convection and convective penetration.  This approach has been described, along with motivating 3-D simulation results, in an article recently published in the Astrophysical Journal (Mao et al. 2024).  A sequence of predicted equilibria for core convection in a zero-age main sequence star of 25 Mʘ is shown for boosted luminosities ranging over 4 orders of magnitude in Fig.1, taken from that article.

Our 3-D simulations revealed that if we break the conservation equation for total energy into 2 separate equations, following the approach of Roxburgh, then the first of these, the kinetic energy equation, comes into statistical equilibrium almost immediately, while the second, the entropy equation, takes much longer to equilibrate.  The terms in both kinetic energy and entropy equations are plotted in Fig. 2 from a 3-D simulation on a medium-resolution grid that we carried out for a very long simulated time.  For the kinetic energy equation, multiple of the terms cannot be known in a 1-D simulation, except by introducing a model.  However, in a short, coarse 3-D simulation, all but the kinetic energy dissipation rate can be determined.  Verification that the kinetic energy is steady in time allows us to solve for the dissipation rate.  In Mao et al. 2024, we show that our result is correct by evaluating this dissipation rate through a much more difficult direct measurement, and we also show that our determination of this dissipation rate converges rapidly as the mesh is refined.

Measuring the kinetic energy dissipation rate enables us to insert this rate into an analysis of the terms in the entropy equation.  We can then solve for the convective entropy flux inside the SB.  A constraint that this flux must vanish at the convective boundary then serves to determine the size and structure of the penetration region.

Volume rendered images of a core convection flow on a high resolution grid of 26883 cells carried out on the Frontera computing system with our PPMstar code are shown in Fig. 3.  Arrows are superimposed to indicate the direction of the dipole convection flow pattern.
